when_to_use: Any patient with suspected anaphylaxis presenting with airway compromise, breathing difficulty, shock, or rapidly progressing systemic symptoms.

key_sections.summary: Assess for airway obstruction (stridor/oral swelling), breathing difficulty (wheeze, respiratory distress), or shock (pale, clammy, hypotension). Skin changes such as urticaria or erythema support diagnosis but are not required.

Administer IM adrenaline immediately into the upper outer thigh. Adult dose: 0.5 mg (0.5 mL of 1:1000). Children: 10 mcg/kg (0.01 mL/kg of 1:1000), min dose 0.1 mL, max dose 0.5 mL. Repeat every 5 minutes as required.
Apply high-flow oxygen, monitor ECG, SpO2, BP. Remove the trigger if known. Position the patient flat or sitting, and avoid walking or standing to prevent cardiovascular collapse.
Obtain IV access. For shock: give rapid 0.9% sodium chloride. Adults: 1000 mL bolus. Children: 10 mL/kg bolus.
Consider steroids for refractory shock or bronchospasm and antihistamines for urticaria or angioedema once stabilised.

If no improvement after two appropriate doses of IM adrenaline, escalate: consider adrenaline infusion, nebulised adrenaline for upper airway obstruction, nebulised salbutamol for bronchospasm, and additional IV fluids.
Monitor for at least 4 hours post-resolution. Reassess airway, breathing, and circulation continuously. Arrange specialist review and consider transfer to critical care setting.
If cardiac arrest occurs, immediately follow ALS algorithm.
